Key elements of the PSM program include: 1) Stringent design standards of equipment which incorporate substantial safety factors.  2) Extensive process safety information that is accurate and up to date.   3) Well trained operating, maintenance, and contractor personnel.  4) Written operating and maintenance procedures.  5) Mechanical integrity procedures of process equipment inspections and quality control.  6) Management of change and pre startup review procedures.  7) Periodic, detailed evaluation of each process area by a team utilizing HAZOP methodology.  8) Regular audits of the PSM program; 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program. The units and their corresponding initial PHA or updated PHA dates are as follows: Ammonia plant-initial PHA complete December 1994; Urea plant initial PHA complete November 1994; UAN plant initial PHA complete September 1994; Ammonia Storage and Loading initial PHA complete March 1994; Offsites initial PHA complete April 1994. _exec_summary.SummaryText:
I.   Executive Summary
Introduction:
The Terra Nitrogen - Blytheville Plant manufactures anhydrous ammonia, granular urea and urea ammonium nitrate (UAN) solution and the by-product carbon dioxide.  Intermediates in the manufacture of these products include nitric acid, urea solution, and ammonium nitrate solution.  The regulated substances, as defined by 40 CFR Part 68, that exceed the threshold quantity are ammonia, chlorine, and hydrogen.
  
It is Terra Nitrogen's policy to prevent accidental releases from the plant by effective process safety management (PSM) programs and procedures. Terra requires participation by plant employees in every element of the PSM program.
   
One way Terra prevents process incidents is by conducting regular analysis of process hazards utilizing current and accurate process safety information.  The operations personnel draft and maintain current operating procedures.  Terra provides timely and comprehensive training for all employees involved in operating and maintaining process equipment.  It is our policy to oversee the activities of contractors and ensure that they are trained to perform their jobs safely.  We follow established pre-startup safety reviews and management of change procedures to ensure that modifications are adequately evaluated for safety and administer a comprehensive mechanical integrity program to ensure that process equipment is maintained in accordance with good engineering practice and accepted industry standards.  We immediately investigate incidents when they do occur so that we can promptly correct deficiencies and learn from the experience. 

It is our policy to maintain a current and accurate written emergency response plan and a well-trained and equipped onsite emergency response team.  We also maintain a system to notify neighbors in the event of a release.  We periodically coordinate emergency response planning with local authorities and participate in joint exercises.  On a regular basis, we audit th

e  PSM program to verify that elements, procedures, and systems are in place and adequate.

Offsite Consequence Analysis:                                                                                                                          The Blytheville Plant Toxic Worst Case Scenario involves ammonia and has offsite impact. The Alternative Release Scenario for ammonia is a 2" pipe break, resulting in the release of 5,400 pounds over a ten minute period. The distance to the toxic endpoint for ammonia (200 ppm) is estimated to be 0.35 miles. The Alternative Release Scenario for chlorine is a 3/8" pipe break resulting in a release of 1,560 pounds over a 120 minute period.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for chlorine (3 ppm) is estimated to be 0.51 miles.  The effect of the alternative toxic releases is limited by the operation of excess flow valves and emergency shutdown procedures in place at the facility.  The Blytheville Plant Flammable Worst Case Scenario involves hydrogen and has offsite impact. The Alternative Release Scenario for hydrogen involves a 1" pipe break, resulting in the release of 540 pounds over a ten minute period.  The distance to the flammable endpoint (3.3% volume - LFL) is estimated to be 0.06 miles.  The effect of the Alternative Flammable release scenario is limited by emergency shutdown procedures.

Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Blytheville Plant has a comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and is subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standard for process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals found at 29 CFR Part 1910.119.  Key elements of the PSM program include: 1) stringent design standards of equipment which incorporate substantial safety factors and include state of the art monitoring and control instrumentation; 2) extensive process safety information that is accurate and up to date; 3) well-trained operating, maintenance, and contract personnel; 4) written operati

ng,maintenance, and safe work procedures; 5) mechanical integrity procedures for process equipment inspections and quality control; 6) management of change and pre-startup safety review procedures; 7)  periodic, detailed evaluation of each process area by a team utilizing HazOp methodology; and 8)  regular audits of the PSM program;and 9) employee participation in every element of the PSM program. 

Five Year Accident History:
There have been no accidental releases from covered processes at the Blytheville Plant within the past five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Emergency Response Program:
The Blytheville Plant also has a comprehensive Emergency Response Program which includes a written plan that is coordinated with local authorities, a 50-plus member emergency response team, and an emergency notification system that utilizes both an in plant alarm and the Community Alert Network telephone system.  Plant personnel have participated in county-wide emergency drills with local responders including the Mississippi County Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the Blytheville Fire Department, the Mississippi County Rescue Squad and personnel from the Blytheville Hospital.  Additionally, the plant exercises its emergency response plan regularly with in-plant drills.
